facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 52 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 52 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 15th February 1955 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1955 arising out of the judgment and order dated the 22nd January, 1955,

facts.text: Calcutta High Court appeal arose from judgment dated 22nd January 1955 of Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas, Alipore, in Trial No. 1 of January Sessions for 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 22nd January, 1955, of the Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas, Alipore, in Trial No. 1 of January Sessions for 1955.

facts.text: Appellant held guilty under s. 376 IPC for committing rape on Sudharani Roy, aged about 14-15 years.

anchor.surface_text: unanimous verdict of guilty returned by the jury holding the appellant guilty under s. 376 of the Indian Penal Code, for having companymitted rape on a young girl, named Sudharani Roy, said to be about 14-15 years of age.

facts.text: Learned trial judge imposed rigorous imprisonment for 5 years on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge, accepting the unanimous verdict of the jury and agreeing with it, imposed a deterrent punishment of rigorous imprisonment for 5 years,

facts.text: Appellant was honorary secretary of Nari Kalyan Ashram for a long time.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the fact that he was in loco parentis to the large number of girls who were the inmates of the Nari Kalyan Ashram of which the appellant had been the secretary for a pretty long time.

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court summarily dismissed appeal on February 15, 1955 without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: directed against the order of a Division Bench of that Court, dated February 15, 1955, summarily dismissing an appeal from the judgment and order dated January 22, 1955,

facts.text: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court granted by Calcutta High Court Bench on March 18, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was heard again on March 17, and on March 18, the learned Chief Justice delivered a judgment which appears at pages 220 to 231 of the record.

facts.text: Appellant was secretary of Nari Kalyan Ashram in Calcutta for girls without homes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the honorary secretary of a large institution for receiving and looking after young girls and women who had numberhomes of their own or had gone astray. It is called the Nari Kalyan Ashram

facts.text: Appellant visited Ashram daily at about 7 p.m. and stayed till midnight or past.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in his capacity as the secretary, used to companye to the Ashram daily in the evening at about 7 p.m., and stay there till mid-night or past mid- night.

facts.text: Appellant committed rape on Narmaya and Sudharani on night of April 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the charge in this case is the offence of rape said to have been companymitted on the two girls Narmaya and Sudharani, one after the other, on the night of April 20, 1954.

facts.text: Police visited Ashram on April 29, 1954 at 10 p.m. regarding escape of girls.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1954, at about 10 p.m., the officer-in-charge of the Maniktala police station, accompanied by Sub-Inspector Nirmal Chandra Kar, went to the Ashram in companynection with companylecting information regarding the escape of some girls from the Ashram.

facts.text: Narmaya and Sudharani alleged rape to police on April 29, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Narmaya and Sudharani are said to have given information to the said officer-in-charge of the police station, alleging rape on them.

facts.text: Rubber sheath found in steel locker in appellant's room, pointed by girls.

anchor.surface_text: They also pointed out a steel locker in the room of the secretary, where, it was alleged, he used to keep rubber sheaths used by him before he had sexual intercourse with each of them. The police officers aforesaid obtained the key from the appellant,

facts.text: Charge-sheet submitted by Maniktala PS officer-in-charge after investigation.

anchor.surface_text: After recording the information, the police officer-in-charge of the Maniktala police station, investigated the case and submitted a charge-sbeet against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant committed to Sessions Court after preliminary inquiry by magistrate on charge u/s 376 IPC on two girls.

anchor.surface_text: After the preliminary inquiry by a magistrate, the appellant was companymitted for trial to the Court of Session on a charge of rape upon the two girls, under s. 376, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Defence of appellant: case false, concocted by police, inmates and Assistant Secretary Tarun Kumar Sarkar.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant was that the case against him was companypletely false and had been companycocted by the police with the help of the inmates of the Ashram and the Assistant Secretary, Tarun Kumar Sarkar who was one of the prosecution witnesses.

facts.text: Prosecution examined 23 witnesses including Sudharani Roy (PW2) and Narmaya (PW5).

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, the prosecution examined 23 witnesses, in support of the case against the accused. The two victims of the alleged outrage by the appellant, were examined, namely, Sudharani Roy, P.W. 2 and Narmaya, P.W. 5,

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous guilty verdict for rape on Sudharani, not guilty for Narmaya (with consent, above 16).

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a unanimous verdict of guilty against the accused in respect of the charge of companymitting rape on Sudharani and a unanimous verdict of riot guilty in respect of the charge of rape on Narmaya. The jury answered the judges question as regards the charge with respect to Narmaya in these words Not guilty as we found with companysent and she is above 16 years of age.

facts.text: Medical evidence estimated Sudharani's age between 13-14 years on May 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The medical estimate of her age was that she was between 13 and 14 years on the date of the X-ray examination, that is May 19, 1954.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 24, 1957 by Sinha J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. October 24. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court at Calcutta, under art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld preliminary objection that certificate was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In view of those authorities of this Court, it is clear that the certificate granted by the High Court is number a proper one. The preliminary objection is, therefore, upheld.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no merit in the appeal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numbermerit in the appeal.

facts.text: Kalyani (PW19), deaf and dumb inmate, corroborated victims' testimony.

anchor.surface_text: Kalyani, P.W. 19, is another young girl who was an inmate of the Ashram on the material dates. She is a girl who was both deaf and dumb, and her intelligence was below numbermal.

facts.text: Rubber sheaths buried underground by woman employee on appellant's ask, recovered by police.

anchor.surface_text: There was also the evidence of a woman employee of the Ashram that she had been asked by the appellant to keep a number of rubber sheaths which she had buried underground, and which on her pointing out, had been discovered by the police.

1957. October 24. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court at Calcutta, under art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, is directed against the order of a Division Bench of that Court,

issues.text: Whether the certificate granted by the High Court under art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution was valid, including whether a coordinate bench could review the summary dismissal by another bench

anchor.surface_text: the learned counsel for the State of West Bengal raised a preliminary objection that the certificate granted by the Bench of the Calcutta High Court presided over by the learned Chief Justice, was bad on the face of the judgment given by him while granting the certificate. We have, therefore, first to examine whether the preliminary objection is sound.

issues.text: Whether there are any grounds on which this Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: But the appeal having been placed before this Court, we have to satisfy ourselves whether there are any grounds on which this Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the learned judge erred in refusing permission to counsel for the appellant to read out the written statement filed on behalf of the appellant at the Sessions stage
Whether there was a serious misdirection in respect of corroboration of the testimony of the alleged victims of rape
Whether the direction as to the age of the girl Sudharani was not complete

arguments.claim: The certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 134(1)(c) is invalid because it was granted on mere questions of fact without complexities of law and a coordinate bench reviewed another bench's decision

anchor.surface_text: the learned counsel for the State of West Bengal raised a preliminary objection that the certificate granted by the Bench of the Calcutta High Court presided over by the learned Chief Justice, was bad on the face of the judgment given by him while granting the certificate. We have, therefore, first to examine whether the preliminary objection is sound. As already stated, the Division Bench before which the appeal came up for admission, summarily dismissed it without giving any reasons.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the companyviction. We have set out the findings of the learned Chief Justice while granting leave to appeal to this Court, in his own words, to appr

arguments.court_reasoning: Certificate on mere facts not law complexities; coordinate bench cannot review another; cites authorities like Haripada Dey

arguments.claim: One Division Bench of High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on decision of another Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the learned Chief Justice and his brother judge, contrary to the legal position that one Bench of the High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench, have, in fact, done so.

arguments.claim: Summary dismissal of appeals is proper practice sanctioned by CrPC especially in jury trials where clear grounds of law needed

anchor.surface_text: Such observations are not conducive to the maintenance of a healthy atmosphere for the administration of justice in the highest Court in the State. Furthermore, the observation almost amounts to a condemnation of the practice of summary dismissal of appeals, especially against orders passed in a case tried by a jury where the appellant has to make out clear grounds of law.

arguments.claim: Certifying under Art. 134(1)(c) is a strong act not mere leave; invalid on mere facts without law complexities

anchor.surface_text: This Court has repeatedly called the attention of the High Courts to the legal position that under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution, it is not a case of granting leave but of certifying that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court. Certifying is a strong word and, therefore, it has been repeatedly pointed out that a High Court is in error in granting a certificate on a mere question of fact, and that the High Court is not justified in passing on an appeal for determination by this Court when there are no complexities of law involved in the case, requiring an authoritative interpretation by this Court.

arguments.claim: There are no grounds for special leave under Art. 136

anchor.surface_text: But the appeal having been placed before this Court, we have to satisfy ourselves whether there are any grounds on which this Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is not a proper one because it was granted on mere questions of fact without complexities of law and a coordinate bench improperly reviewed another bench's summary dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has repeatedly called the attention of the High Courts to the legal position that under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, it Is number a case of granting leave but of certifying that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court. Certifying is a strong word and, therefore, it has been repeatedly pointed out that a High Court is in error in granting a certificate on a mere question of fact, and that the High Court is number justified in passing on an appeal for determination by this Court when there are numbercomplexities of law involved in the case, requiring an authoritative interpretation by this Court. On the face of the judgment of the learned Chief Justice, the leave granted cannot be sustained vide the case of Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal  1 , and a number of decisions of this Court referred to therein. In view of those authorities of this Court, it is clear that the certificate granted by the High Court is number a proper one. The preliminary objection is, therefore, upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied precedents requiring certificate only for legal complexities not facts; one Division Bench cannot review coordinate bench; summary dismissal proper practice; cites Haripada Dey and other SC authorities.

holdings.text: There are no grounds on which the Supreme Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: But the appeal having been placed before this Court, we have to satisfy ourselves whether there are any grounds on which this Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examined merits of appeal points and found no substance, upholding trial court's charge and jury verdict.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge rightly refused permission to read out the accused's written statement to the jury as no provision in CrPC for Sessions trials unlike magistrate warrant cases, and inadmissible for jury.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these companysiderations, in our opinion, the learned Sessions Judge rightly refused to allow the written statement put in by the appellant, to be read out before the jury.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No CrPC s.256 equivalent for Sessions; s.342 alternative; risk of irrelevant matter before jury.

holdings.text: No misdirection on corroboration; rule of prudence requires warning but not mandatory corroboration of prosecutrix (not accomplice); jury may convict on uncorroborated testimony if satisfied; charge correct.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the learned Sessions Judge was fully justified in telling the jury that there was numberrule of law or practice that there must be companyroboration in every case, before a companyviction for rape. If the jury had been apprised of the necessity, ordinarily speaking, of companyroboration of the evidence of the prosecutrix, it is for the jury to decide whether or number it will companyvict on the uncorroborated testimony of a prosecutrix in the particular circumstances of the case before it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge warned on prudence, distinguished prosecutrix from accomplice; sufficient corroboration available (Kalyani, circumstances); cites Rameshwar v. State of Rajasthan.

holdings.text: Direction on age of Sudharani complete and fair; ossification not sure guide but with other evidence (register, etc.) and benefit of doubt instructed; under 16, consent immaterial.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the learned Sessions Judge placed the evidence pro and company very fairly and fully, and left it to the jury to companye to their own companyclusion. According to the medical evidence, Sudharani was between 13 to 14 years of age on the relevant date, whereas the other girl in respect of whom, the accused was acquitted, was found by the medical test to be between 15 and 16 years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge covered all evidence, ossification, benefit of doubt; medical supports under 16; jury sensibly distinguished girls' ages.

holdings.text: No merit in the appeal overall.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numbermerit in the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All substantive contentions lack substance; fair charge, sufficient evidence, proper jury verdict.

holdings.text: One Division Bench of High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment over another coordinate Division Bench's decision.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the learned Chief Justice and his brother judge, companytrary to the legal position that one Bench of the High Court has numberjurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench, have, in fact, done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established legal position on High Court internal jurisdiction.

precedents.case_name: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: A High Court certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) cannot be granted on mere questions of fact or without complexities of law requiring authoritative interpretation by the Supreme Court

precedents.citation: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan 1

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan 1

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: No rule of practice requires corroboration of prosecutrix testimony in every rape case; it is a rule of prudence to be considered, but conviction possible on uncorroborated testimony if satisfied
precedents.cited_holding: The only rule of law is that this rule of prudence must be present to the mind of the judge or the jury as the case may be and be understood and appreciated by him or them. There is no rule of practice that there must, in every case, be corroboration before a conviction can be allowed to stand.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has repeatedly called the attention of the High Courts to the legal position that under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, it Is number a case of granting leave but of certifying that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court. Certifying is a strong word and, therefore, it has been repeatedly pointed out that a High Court is in error in granting a certificate on a mere question of fact, and that the High Court is number justified in passing on an appeal for determination by this Court when there are numbercomplexities of law involved in the case, requiring an authoritative interpretation by this Court. On the face of the judgment of the learned Chief Justice, the leave granted cannot be sustained vide the case of Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal  1 , and a number of decisions of this Court referred to therein. In view of those authorities of this Court, it is clear that the certificate granted by the High Court is number a proper one. The preliminary objection is, therefore, upheld.
In our opinion, there is numbermerit in the appeal.
